paper_title: X-Reasoner: Towards Generalizable Reasoning Across Modalities and Domains

sections.title: Abstract
sections.content: Recent proprietary models (e.g., o3) have begun to demonstrate strong multimodal reasoning capabilities. Yet, most existing open-source research concentrates on training text-only reasoning models, with evaluations limited to mainly mathematical and general-domain tasks. Therefore, it remains unclear how to effectively extend reasoning capabilities beyond text input and general domains. This paper explores a fundamental research question: Is reasoning generalizable across modalities and domains? Our findings support an affirmative answer: General-domain text-based post-training can enable such strong generalizable reasoning. Leveraging this finding, we introduce X-Reasoner, a vision-language model post-trained solely on general-domain text for generalizable reasoning, using a two-stage approach: an initial supervised fine-tuning phase with distilled long chain-of-thoughts, followed by reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards. Experiments show that X-Reasoner successfully transfers reasoning capabilities to both multimodal and out-of-domain settings, outperforming existing state-of-the-art models trained with in-domain and multimodal data across various general and medical benchmarks (Figure 1). Additionally, we find that X-Reasoner's performance in specialized domains can be further enhanced through continued training on domain-specific text-only data. Building upon this, we introduce X-Reasoner-Med, a medical-specialized variant that achieves new state of the art on numerous text-only and multimodal medical benchmarks.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Reasoning has emerged as foundational capability in language models, paving the way for new paradigm known as test-time scaling (OpenAI, 2024). This paradigm allows models to achieve consistent gains in complex reasoning tasks through scaling compute resources during inference. Recent proprietary models, such as o3 (OpenAI, 2025), have begun to demonstrate strong multimodal reasoning capabilities. However, existing open-source research primarily focuses on advancing text-only reasoning, employing post-training techniques such as long CoT (Chain-of-Thought) distillation and reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards (DeepSeek-AI et al., 2025; Hu et al., 2025). While these efforts have resulted in powerful reasoning models, their evaluation has largely been confined to math and general-domain text benchmarks. Consequently, it remains uncertain how reasoning capabilities can effectively generalize beyond text inputs and general-domain contexts. Recently, growing body of open-source work has started addressing multimodal reasoning, i.e., extending reasoning to inputs that include both vision and language (Wang et al., 2025; Meng et al., 2025; Guo et al., 2024). Yet, current multimodal approaches often rely heavily on curating multimodal datasets which are tailored to specific tasks or domains, limiting their generalisability. In this work, we ask fundamental, yet under-explored question: Is reasoning generalizable across modalities and domains? Specifically, we investigate whether such generalizable reasoning can be achieved through general-domain text-based reasoning post-training. Beyond scientific significance, this question is also motivated by the practical advantages of general domain text-only training: i.e. its compute efficiency and the abundance and verifiability of general-domain textual reasoning data, which together allow us to avoid the cost and complexity of curating multimodal or domain-specific data. Our hypothesis is that text-based post-training, when carefully designed, can impart universal reasoning patterns that robustly transfer across both unseen domains and input modalities. To investigate our hypothesis, we conduct an extensive empirical study using two-stage text-only post-training recipe: supervised fine-tuning (SFT) on general-domain text data with distilled long CoTs, followed by reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards (RLVR) using mathematical textual questions. Remarkably, this pure textual training regimen proves sufficient to instill strong reasoning capabilities, enabling high performance not only on general-domain tasks but also on complex multimodal and domain-specific tasks. This finding suggests that the core structure of reasoning can indeed be acquired from general-domain text alone. Building upon these insights, we introduce X-REASONER, 7B vision-language model post-trained with the proposed recipe. Despite being trained only for text-based reasoning, X-REASONER achieves superior performance on suite of both text-only and multimodal reasoning benchmarks, outperforming prior state-of-the-art 7B models that were explicitly trained with multimodal reasoning supervision, on challenging tasks including MMMU, MMMU-Pro and MathVista. We further demonstrate that the improvement from X-REASONER can generalize to specialized domains such as medicine. To boost in-domain performance even further, we explore the impact of incorporating domain-specific textual data. To this end, we introduce X-REASONER-MED, medical-specialized variant of X-REASONER, which undergoes additional post-training on medical domain text. XREASONER-MED sets new records on numerous textual and multimodal medical tasks. Our key contributions can be summarized as the following: 1. Generalizable Reasoning Study: We conduct an in-depth study of whether reasoning capabilities trained on general-domain text can generalize across input modalities and domains. We find that combining SFT and RL yields the strongest gains, and that math-based data serves as strong anchor, though domain-specific data remains important for specialization. 2. Introduction of X-REASONER: We propose an effective post-training recipe for vision-language reasoning models that relies entirely on general-domain text-based data. X-REASONER improves performance across modalities and domains, remarkably, achieving SOTA on challenging general-domain multimodal benchmarks. 3. Medical Domain Extension via X-REASONER-MED: We present X-REASONER-MED, domain-adapted variant of X-REASONER trained on medical text, setting new 7B-scale records across medical text-only and multimodal tasks.

sections.title: 2 A Journey Towards Generalizable Reasoning
sections.content: Figure 2: (Left) Our recipe for generalizable reasoning: based on an instruction-tuned VLM, we first conduct SFT on general-domain text data with distilled long CoTs. This is followed by RLVR on mathematical textual questions. This resulting model, X-REASONER, exhibits significantly enhanced reasoning capabilities across modalities and domains. (Right) Model performance on MMMU-Pro (multimodal task) steadily improves at each stage of our recipe. In this section, we embark on systematic exploration to understand whether generalizable reasoning can be effectively acquired through general-domain text-based post-training. Here, we define generalizable reasoning as the ability to transfer reasoning capabilities not only across different task distributions but also across diverse modalities and specialized domains. To thoroughly address this question, we break it down into two sub-questions corresponding to two predominant post-training strategies used to foster reasoning: SFT and RL. Starting from an instruction-tuned vision-language model (VLM) capable of following instructions yet benefiting less from CoT prompting (see Section 2.1), we perform detailed empirical study utilizing these two post-training methods. Our objective is to identify robust and effective recipe that achieves strong, generalizable reasoning capabilities purely through general-domain text-based training. 2.1 RQ1: Will Text-only SFT Improve Generalizable Reasoning? Our first research question investigates whether reasoning trained solely via SFT on general-domain textual data can generalize beyond the training distribution. Specifically, we study two key aspects: (1) the extent to which generalization can occur across domains and modalities, and (2) the essential role of reasoning in enabling such generalization. Extent of Generalization We begin by examining whether reasoning capabilities acquired through text-only SFT can generalize across distributional shifts and more importantly whether generaldomain text-only SFT can transfer across domains and input modalities. We start with cross-distribution investigation where we fine-tune an instruction-tuned VLM, Qwen2.5-VL-7B-Instruct (Bai et al., 2025) using text-only MedQA (Jin et al., 2021), specialized medical QA dataset. The training signal comprises detailed long-COT reasoning traces, distilled via rejection sampling (Huang et al., 2023; Zelikman et al., 2022) from QwQ-32B (Team, 2025b). We then evaluate the models generalization on an out-of-distribution task: MMLU-ProHealth, the healthcare subset of MMLU-Pro (Wang et al., 2024b). The full training and evaluation details are provided in Sections 2.3 and 3. As shown in the top rows of Table 1, all the SFT approaches consistently transfers the improvements from the source task (MedQA) to the target task (MMLU-Pro-Health), demonstrating strong cross-task generalization from text-only SFT. To further explore the scope of generalization, we perform SFT using OpenThoughts-114k (Team, 2025a), text-only dataset covering math and science reasoning distilled from DeepSeek-R1 (DeepSeek-AI et al., 2025). Results in Table 1 show the SFT model yields consistent performance gains across three generalization axes: cross-domain (X-domain), cross-modality (X-modality) and the intersection of the two axes. This indicates that SFT with general-domain text-data already shows strong generalization capabilities. In addition, while CoT prompting alone provides some transferable gains, they are notably smaller compared with SFT, indicating that the VLMs inherent CoT capability prior to SFT is limited and CoT SFT is essential to fully unlock generalizable reasoning. Role of Reasoning in Generalization To isolate the contribution of reasoning, we compare models trained with and without explicit CoT supervision: (1) non-CoT SFT model trained directly on input-label pairs, and (2) CoT SFT model trained with reasoning traces. Across all experiments in Table 1, the CoT-based SFT model consistently outperforms its non-CoT counterpart. Even among 3 the baseline models, those equipped with CoT prompting outperform those without it, underscoring that explicit reasoning is prerequisite for high performance on reasoning-centric tasks. Furthermore, we observe that CoT-based models not only perform better in-distribution but also exhibit stronger transfer capabilities. Notably, the performance lift from CoT SFT over the CoT baseline is substantially larger than the corresponding improvement from non-CoT SFT over the non-CoT baseline across all settings. This suggests that explicit reasoning is the key to achieving both the highest in-distribution performance and the optimal generalization across new domains and modalities. Forced-Exiting: Mitigating Endless Thinking in Long-CoT SFT While long-CoT SFT effectively learns transferrable reasoning patterns, such as self-reflection, verification, and correction (see qualitative analyses in Appendix H), we observe recurring challenge: the model occasionally fails to terminate its responses. Specifically, the model continues generating tokens indefinitely without producing stop signal. Such endless thinking occurs approximately 17% of generations for both MedQA and MMLU-Pro-Health tasks, as reported in  (Table 2)  . Upon closer inspection, these failure cases are often characterized by verbose, repetitive output, where the model persistently attempts to re-think or double-check, an artifact likely stemming from the reasoning mechanism introduced during long-CoT SFT (DeepSeek-AI et al., 2025). To address this, we implement forced-exiting mechanism inspired by the method introduced in Muennighoff et al. (2025). This involves appending designated stop token </think> once the output sequence reaches predefined length threshold. This soft intervention encourages the model to wrap up its reasoning process within reasonable token budget. As shown in Table 2, applying forced-exiting effectively reduces endless thinking, thereby improving final task accuracy. Forced-exiting provides practical and effective solution to address the endless thinking behavior in long-CoT SFT, improving both reliability and downstream task performance. 4 2.2 RQ2: Will Mathematical Text-only RL Improve Generalizable Reasoning? Reinforcement Learning (RL) has become an effective approach for training models to reason. In this section, we explore whether mathematical text-only RL can promote generalizable reasoning. Learning Algorithm We employ GRPO (Shao et al., 2024) as our RL algorithm (Sutton, 1988). GRPO has recently become favored over algorithms such as PPO (Schulman et al., 2017) as it does not require an additional value function. Instead, GRPO computes the advantage by comparing responses within each query-specific group. The detailed formulation is provided in Appendix A. To stabilize and improve GRPO training, we incorporate several enhancements inspired by recent work (Liu et al., 2025a; Yu et al., 2025): (1) using higher upper clipping threshold (clip-higher), which promotes sample diversity and mitigates entropy collapse; (2) employing token-level policy gradient loss, which normalizes the loss by the total number of tokens within batch, thus addressing the response-length bias present in GRPO; and (3) reducing or entirely removing the KL penalty, change beneficial in training models performing long chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning, where the policy distribution may significantly diverge from the reference model. Verifiable Rewards Rather than relying on learned reward model, which often encounters rewardhacking issues (Gao et al., 2022), we directly utilize the final accuracy on verifiable tasks as our reward metric. Specifically, response receives reward of = 1 if it matches the ground truth answer under semantic equivalence (i.e., is equivalent(ˆy, y)), and = 0 otherwise. We omit format rewards, as our policy model already adheres well to instruction formatting. The Role of Training Data: Math as Generalization Anchor central question in text-only RL is: What type of training data best supports reasoning generalization? While reasoning models are often fine-tuned on domain-specific datasets, we hypothesize that mathematics serves as an especially effective domain for promoting generalizable reasoning, as math tasks naturally elicit long, structured chains of thought that may transfer more effectively across domains. To test this, we compare RL fine-tuning on two data sources: (1) math textual questions from Orz (Hu et al., 2025), and (2) MedQA, domain-specific medical textual QA dataset. Results in Table 3 reveal clear asymmetry: models trained on math data not only improve on math benchmarks (e.g., GSM8K, MathVista), but also show strong gains on out-of-domain medical tasks. In contrast, models trained on MedQA excel in medical benchmarks but do not consistently improve math tasks. This suggests that math serves as an anchor domain, whose reasoning structure is sufficiently rich and general to support cross-domain&modality transfer. Supporting this, we observe in Table 3 that math-trained models consistently generate longer responses across benchmarks. Furthermore, across all models, responses to math tasks are longer than those to medical tasks, highlighting maths inherent demand for extended reasoning. That said, domain-specific data remains important. RL fine-tuning on MedQA yields the best performance on medical tasks, indicating that in-domain RL is still critical for achieving optimal performance in specialized domains. However, domain-specific data remains essential for optimal performance in specialized contexts. RL vs SFT Prior work has positioned RL as powerful yet volatile method for promoting generalizable reasoning (Chu et al., 2025), while SFT is widely recognized for its stability and efficacy in capturing structured reasoning patterns. However, RL is often plagued by training instability and convergence issues, particularly when applied in isolation (Yeo et al., 2025). To better understand their relative strengths, we conduct direct comparison between RL and SFT in fostering 5 generalization across task distributional shifts, domain shifts and modality transitions. Specifically, we compare general-domain text-only SFT (trained on general-domain OpenThoughts data) and RL (trained on math questions from Orz), and their combination (SFT + RL). Alongside generaldomain text task (MMLU-Pro), we evaluated the models in three distinct generalization settings: cross-domain (medical text: MMLU-Pro-Health), cross-modality (multimodal: MMMU-Pro), cross domain&modality (multimodal medical: NEJM Image Challenge). In Table 4, we first observe that general-domain SFT and RL can both significantly improve from baseline across all the generalization settings, indicating both SFT and RL can elicit generalizable reasoning. We further notice that pure RL is overall slightly worse than SFT. This performance gap can be attributed to RLs difficulty in learning long-CoT reasoning from scratch, evidenced by its shorter, less structured outputs. In contrast, SFT excels at acquiring rich CoT patterns through supervised distillation, yielding significantly longer and more coherent responses. Interestingly, when RL is applied after SFT, it benefits from the structured reasoning foundation established by SFT, and further refines the models capabilities via RLVR. We also observe that RL + SFT is able to regulate the endless thinking issue from SFT as the percentage of responses that exceeds the maximum length decreases during RL training, as shown in the training response clip ratio in Figure 5. In summary, the hybrid approach, generaldomain text-only SFT + RL, achieves the best results across all generalization settings, effectively combining SFTs stability and inductive strength with RLs reward-guided optimization2. Therefore, we conclude our investigation by consolidating our findings into coherent training recipe, illustrated in Figure 2, culminating in powerful generalizable reasoning model named X-REASONER. Specifically, initialized with Qwen2.5-VL-7B-Instruct (Bai et al., 2025), our training recipe follows: Step 1: text-only general-domain Long-CoT SFT. We begin by applying SFT to elicit explicit structured reasoning capabilities using long-CoT reasoning traces. We train our model on the general-domain open-thoughts/OpenThoughts-114k dataset (Team, 2025a). This dataset contains curated reasoning traces on 114k math, coding and science questions, distilled by the DeepSeek-R1 model. We fine-tune the model for 4 epochs with learning rate of 1 105. Step 2: text-only math RLVR. After SFT, we further refine our model using RL with verifiable rewards to enhance its reasoning accuracy and generalization. We trainin our model on Orz-math-57k, set of 57k mathematical textual questions curated by Hu et al. (2025). During this stage, we set the total training episodes/epochs to 3, use learning rate of 3 106, global batch size of 128, and sample 8 rollouts per query with maximum response length of 4,096 tokens. Detailed hyperparameters for each training stage are provided in Appendix B. The SFT stage was conducted using 8 40GB A100 GPUs over 8 hours, and the RLVR stage utilized 32 40GB A100 GPUs for approximately 56 hours. We provide visualization of training dynamics in Appendix G. 2We also conduct more controlled comparison between SFT and RL, both trained on the same MedQA data, and arrive at the same conclusion  (Table 9)  .

sections.title: 3 A Comprehensive Evaluation of X-REASONER
sections.content: Evaluation Setup To thoroughly assess the generalizability of X-REASONER, we evaluate its performance across four distinct settings: (1) General-domain text-only tasks; (2) Generaldomain multimodal tasks (X-modality); (3) Specialized-domain text-only tasks (X-domain); and (4) Specialized-domain multimodal tasks (X-modality&domain). Detailed descriptions of these tasks can be found in Appendix D. For inference, we utilize the vLLM backend (Kwon et al., 2023). Consistent with recent findings on reproducibility (Hochlehnert et al., 2025), we observe performance variability even under greedy decoding (i.e., temperature=0), attributed to hardware differences, software stack inconsistencies, runtime environments, etc. In this study, we report greedy decoding results to compare with previous studies. In addition, to ensure the robustness and reproducibility, we report three additional metrics computed over five runs at temperature = 0.3: average accuracy, majority-vote accuracy, and pass@n accuracy. Majority-vote accuracy aligns with the self-consistency method introduced by Wang et al. (2023), which has proven effective for scaling up parallel test-time evaluation. Pass@n accuracy provides further insight into the models effective exploration of the answer space, indicating potential performance gains achievable through additional reinforcement learning. Unless otherwise indicated, we consistently use CoT prompting templates for both baselines and X-REASONER evaluations. Complete exact prompt templates are provided in Appendix C. Additionally, we apply forced-exiting mechanism as described by Muennighoff et al. (2025), capping output generation at 4,096 tokens. This mechanism not only improves memory efficiency but also effectively handles endless thinking cases, as elaborated in Section 2.1. Figure 3: Comparing X-REASONER and baseline on text-only benchmarks and multi-modal benchmarks. Despite being trained with general-domain text-only data, X-REASONER can significantly improve multi-modal benchmarks, showing the generalization of X-REASONERs reasoning. 3.1 X-REASONERs Cross-Modality Generalization In Figure 3, we assess the cross-modality generalization capabilities of X-REASONER. We first validate its effectiveness on text-only tasks, observing significant performance gains across benchmarks such as MMLU-Pro and GSM8K. Crucially, these improvements robustly transfer to multimodal contexts, reflected consistently across average, majority vote, and pass@5 accuracy. Such consistent improvements indicate not only overall superior reasoning capability, but also suggest that X-REASONER has more effective and expansive search space for further improvements. Comparisons against SOTA multimodal reasoning models are presented in Table 5. X-REASONER achieves SOTA on MMMU, MMMU-Pro and MathVista, while remaining competitive on others. Notably, these SOTA models are extensively trained on multimodal data, underscoring the critical finding that text-only reasoning training alone is sufficientand likely accounts for the majority of learning necessary for effective multimodal reasoning. Qualitative analysis in Appendix highlights that X-REASONER consistently generates more sophisticated reasoning outputs compared to the baseline. Reasoning patterns demonstrated by XREASONER include detailed planning, verification (e.g., wait steps), and error correction. In the 7 cross-modality setting, X-REASONER seamlessly integrates visual information into its reasoning chains, providing step-by-step reasoning with verification. For example, in Table 11, X-REASONER methodically reviews all bar values in plot, avoiding the oversight errors prevalent in the baseline. X-REASONER also identifies and corrects mistakes within its reasoning process. These observations reinforce our conclusion that X-REASONER successfully internalizes generic reasoning patterns through text-only training, effectively extending them across modalities. Ablation Study: Is X-REASONER simply solving the text-solvable examples? potential limitation in evaluating vision-language models is their tendency to rely on text-based shortcuts, solving tasks without genuinely integrating visual information. To rigorously confirm that the crossmodality generalization observed with X-REASONER is not merely due to improved text-only shortcut solutions, we conduct an ablation experiment. Specifically, we identify and remove text-solvable examples and assess whether performance gains persist afterward. To identify these text-solvable examples, we mask visual inputs for multimodal tasks previously evaluated in Section 3.1, performing text-only evaluations using both X-REASONER and the baseline Qwen2.5-VL-7B-Instruct. For each model, we sample three independent responses per question and eliminate examples consistently solved through text alone. Table 6 summarizes the number of remaining examples after removing text-solvable examples for each task, along with the corresponding model performances. While substantial number of textsolvable instances were identified, these primarily reflect models textual reasoning shortcuts rather than dataset issues (Yue et al., 2024b). Crucially, X-REASONER maintains performance advantages over the baseline after text-only solvable examples are excluded, affirming true multimodal reasoning capabilities. This confirms that X-REASONER effectively utilizes visual context within the reasoning framework acquired through text-only training. While X-REASONER is trained exclusively on general-domain text data, we further probe the benefits of domain-specific adaptation by developing X-REASONER-MED, which extends X-REASONER with additional training using medical text data. Evaluation Setup Our evaluation includes three text-only medical tasks: MMLU-Pro-Health (the healthcare subset of MMLU-Pro (Wang et al., 2024b), selected following the setup in (Chen et al., 2024a)), MedQA (the original USMLE version), and MedQA (4-ops: the four-choice version). For multimodal medical evaluations, we utilize healthcare subsets of MMMU (Yue et al., 2024a) and MMMU-Pro (Yue et al., 2024b), designated as MMMU-Health and MMMU-Pro-Health respectively. We also include MedXpertQA-MM (Zuo et al., 2025), OmniMedVQA (Hu et al., 2024) and NEJM Image Challenge (New England Journal of Medicine, 2025), which are specifically designed to evaluate medical knowledge and reasoning. Figure 4: Comparing X-REASONER, X-REASONER-MED and baseline on text and multimodal medical benchmarks. X-REASONER, trained with general-domain text-only data brings consistent improvement across medical tasks. X-REASONER-MED, obtained by continued training of XREASONER on medical text data, further improves medical domain performance. Results Figure 4 shows X-REASONER demonstrates robust cross-domain and cross-modality generalization capabilities, surpassing baseline models on both textual and multimodal medical tasks. Remarkably, as detailed in Figure 1, X-REASONER surpassing or matching previous SOTA on MedXpertQA-MM and MMMU-Health, despite previous SOTA models being explicitly trained on multimodal medical data. Qualitative assessments in Appendix further illustrate X-REASONERs effective integration of visual information and medical domain-specific reasoning. As an example, X-REASONER accurately identifies medical patterns, such as correctly recognizing white matter abnormalities indicative of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy in histology slides  (Table 12)  . Takeaway 3.3.1 X-REASONER substantially enhances medical task performance, confirming its strong capability for cross-domain and cross-modality generalization. X-REASONER-MED: Enhancing Medical Performance While X-REASONER shows substantial improvements on medical tasks, our analysis in Section 2.2 highlights the critical role of domainspecific data for achieving optimal in-domain performance. This leads us to investigate whether additional medical-domain text data can further enhance X-REASONERs performance. To explore this, we extend X-REASONERs training with text-only MedQA data. Specifically, we perform SFT with distilled CoTs from QwQ-32B (Team, 2025b), followed by RLVR using the same MedQA data. 9 The resulting model, X-REASONER-MED, achieves further improvements across medical benchmarks. As depicted in Figure 4, X-REASONER-MED consistently surpasses X-REASONER in terms of average and majority vote accuracies. Notably, X-REASONER sometimes attains higher pass@n scores, suggesting it explores broader search space. Conversely, X-REASONER-MED, benefiting from targeted medical-domain fine-tuning, already leverages this search space more effectively but potentially with reduced room for further gains. Nevertheless, as highlighted in Figure 1, XREASONER-MED sets new SOTA performance for both text-only and multimodal medical tasks, validating our hypothesis that combining general text-based reasoning with domain-specific textbased fine-tuning unlocks substantial additional performance gains for specialized domains. Takeaway 3.3.2 X-REASONER-MED, resulting from continued training of X-REASONER with medical textonly data, achieves further performance enhancements and establishes new SOTA results in text and multimodal medical benchmarks.

sections.title: 4 Related Work
sections.content: In the context of RL, several methods have been proposed for learning multimodal reasoning. Notable examples include VFT (Liu et al., 2025b), MM-Eureka (Meng et al., 2025), Vision-R1 (Huang et al., 2025a), R1-V (Chen et al., 2025), and the framework proposed by Zhou et al. (2025). These works demonstrate how RL can be used to refine reasoning abilities within VLMs. Peng et al. (2025b) present two-stage RL approach that leverages both text-based and multimodal data, while Deng et al. (2025) explore an iterative training scheme alternating between SFT and RL on multimodal inputs, beginning with distillation of CoT reasoning from image captions. On the SFT side, reasoning is commonly distilled from captions or responses synthesized by VLMs. Methods such as MaMMOTH (Guo et al., 2024; Jia et al., 2025), Vision-R1 (Huang et al., 2025a), R1-OneVision (Yang et al., 2025), and Llava-CoT (Xu et al., 2024) follow this strategy to infuse reasoning into multimodal models during SFT. An alternative approach involves linking text-based reasoning model with vision encoder to incorporate visual grounding (Peng et al., 2025a). Recently, there has been growing interest in applying reasoning techniques to the medical domain, initially focusing on the text modality (Zhang et al., 2025a; Huang et al., 2025b; Chen et al., 2024a). Subsequently, researchers have begun exploring RL-based training on multimodal medical datasets to enhance multimodal reasoning performance, e.g., Pan et al. (2025) and Lai et al. (2025).

sections.title: 5 Discussions and Limitations
sections.content: While we show X-REASONER effectively equips vision-language models with generalizable reasoning capabilities, we acknowledge several limitations that offer opportunities for future work: Base Model Constraints Prior studies have emphasized the importance of starting from pretrained base checkpoints, rather than instruction-tuned models, to better incentivize the emergence of reasoning behaviors (DeepSeek-AI et al., 2025; Hu et al., 2025). However, in our case, we are constrained by computational resources and the lack of base VLMs in the recent open-source releases, limiting our ability to empirically validate these claims. Model Scale and Backbone Diversity Prior work suggests that larger models tend to exhibit stronger reasoning capabilities (DeepSeek-AI et al., 2025). However, due to computational constraints, our model size is limited to 7B parameters. We also focused exclusively on the Qwen-VL series and did not evaluate other publicly available VLMs. Task Scope Our evaluation primarily targets mathematical questions and multiple-choice questions across general and medical domains. While these benchmarks provide clear, verifiable supervision for assessing reasoning capabilities, they do not capture the full spectrum of real-world reasoning challenges. In particular, we have not tested our approach on open-ended generation, interactive dialogue, or instruction-following scenarios. Understanding how reasoning generalizes to such unconstrained settings remains an important area for future exploration.

sections.title: 6 Conclusion
sections.content: In this work, we introduce X-REASONER, simple yet effective post-training recipe that enhances the reasoning capabilities of VLMs using only general-domain text-based supervision from combined SFT + RL strategy. Through extensive experiments, we demonstrate that the reasoning skills acquired via X-REASONERs text-only training pipeline generalize effectively across modalities and domains, surpassing prior SOTA trained with in-domain multimodal data. We further introduce XREASONER-MED, domain-specialized variant of X-REASONER trained on medical text which achieves new SOTA on range of medical benchmarks across both text-only and multimodal settings. Our findings underscore the surprising power of textual supervision for learning transferable reasoning in multimodal models. We leave to future work the exploration of continued in-domain multimodal SFT/RL to further strengthen domain-specific and multimodal reasoning capabilities.

sections.title: B Hyperparameters
sections.content: In this section, we discuss the hyperparameters used in our SFT and RL experiments. B.1 Supervised Fine-Tuning For the SFT experiments, we use the AdamW optimizer (Loshchilov & Hutter, 2019) with learning rate of 1 105, weight decay of 0.0, β1 = 0.9 and β2 = 0.999. We adopt multiplicative learning rate scheduler with decay rate of 0.8 for each epoch. The training batch size is set as 4 per device and we used 32 GPUs in total. The context length is truncated to 4096 tokens for each sequence. Each dataset will be trained for 4 epochs. B.2 Reinforcement Learning Throughout our experiments, we set KL coefficient β = 1.0 102 and the clip ratio ϵ = 0.2. For each example, we sample 8 responses with maximum length of 4096 tokens and sampling temperature of 1.0. When updating the actor model, we use AdamW (Loshchilov & Hutter, 2019) and set the learning rate as 3.0 106 and weight decay as 1.0 102. warm-up learning rate scheduler is used by using 10% of the total training steps. Gradient norm is applied with threshold of 1.0. global batch size (calculated across all devices) is set as 128. All the training are stopped on the convergence of the reward value on the training set.

This complex reasoning patterns is successfully transferred to cross-modality setups where X-REASONER seamlessly integrates the vision information into the reasoning chain, and provides detailed step-by-step reasoning with verification for review/correc19 tion.
